contentrichtext.text: {{semiprotected|small=yes}}{{pp-move-indef}} [[Image:Soleil-Royal mp3h9369.jpg|thumb|Poop deck of a model of the [[French ship Soleil-Royal (1670)|''Soleil-Royal'']], as seen from the [[forecastle]] (fo'c'sle)]] In [[naval architecture]], a '''poop deck''' is a [[deck (ship)|deck]] that forms the [[roof]] of a cabin built in the rear, or "[[aft]]", part of the [[superstructure]] of a [[ship]]. The name originates from the [[French language|French]] word for [[stern]], ''la poupe'', from [[Latin]] ''puppis''. Thus the poop deck is technically a '''stern deck''', which in sailing ships was usually elevated as the roof of the stern or "after" cabin, also known as the "poop cabin". In sailing ships, with the [[helmsman]] at the stern, an elevated position was ideal for both [[navigation]] and observation of the crew and sails.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hms-victory.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=105&Itemid=541|title=Poop Deck|work=HMS Victory|publisher=[[Portsmouth Historic Dockyard]]|accessdate=27 April 2013|quote=Located at the stern, this short deck takes its name from the Latin word puppis - which means after deck or rear. Guns were rarely carried on this deck. It was mainly used as a viewpoint and signalling platform. The poop deck also gave protection to the men at the wheel and provided a roof for the captain's cabin. The ropes controlling the yards (spars) and sails of the main and mizzen masts were operated from the poop deck.}}</ref> On modern, motorized warships, the ship functions which were once carried out on the poop deck have been moved to the [[Bridge (nautical)|bridge]], usually located on the superstructure in the center of the ship or the island on the starboard side in the case of [[aircraft carrier]]s. ==See also== *[[Deck (ship)#Common names for decks]] ==References== ;Notes {{reflist}} <!--spacing--> {{Sailing ship elements}} [[Category:Sailing ship components]] [[Category:Ship construction]] [[Category:Nautical terms]]
